funding: We are supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant 81471054) and the Inno­vation Project of Guangxi Graduate Education (grant JGY2015128)
introduction: An important determinant of whether or not 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) will ultimately cause a global pandemic is its ability to become established upon its importation to a new country. Cases of 2019-nCoV infection have so far been reported in 24 countries, yet little human-to-human transmission outside of China has occurred.

The key quantity governing whether or not 2019-nCoV can establish and generate a sustained outbreak on arrival in a new country is the reproduction number, R, which represents the average number of individuals that each infector will transmit the virus to. If R is greater than 1, sustained transmission can occur; if R is less than 1, then chains of transmission will simply stutter out.

Tolerance versus resistance to infection: I read with interest the excellent Review on sepsis immunopathology by Ignacio Rubio and colleagues,[1] which covered in detail the known (and more crucially, the unknown) developments in sepsis-related research. However, one very relevant nuance was perhaps overlooked.

Despite immunosuppression being a substantial risk factor for sepsis, as the authors note, a reasonable amount of evidence points to immuno­ suppression being protective in a given sepsis episode. For example, in a large, retrospective hospital dataset, Donnelly and colleagues[2] showed that in-hospital mortality for severe sepsis in patients with solid organ transplant was nearly half that of patients without (5·5% vs 9·4%). This protective effect remained (albeit weakened) after adjusting for relevant confounders—with an odds ratio of 0·83 (95% CI 0·79–0·87) for inhospital mortality.[2] In a smaller study by Kalil and colleagues,[3 123] solid organ transplant recipients with blood culture-proven sepsis were age and sex matched with 246 controls. Despite having more comorbidities and higher scores on the quick sepsisrelated organ failure assessment, solid organ transplant recipients had lower 28-day mortality, with a hazard ratio of 0·22 (95% CI 0·09–0·54).[3] Finally, in a large Danish cohort study,4 3092 renal transplant recipients were matched with population controls, and despite having approxi­mately ten times the incidence of pneumonia, the mortality rate in each episode was approximately half that of the general population (7% vs 14%).

Clearly, other reasons for patients with solid organ transplant having greater survival than those without are plausible (ie, enhanced care, care in a tertiary centre, or earlier presentation), but this intriguing finding deserves explanation and should be explored further in translational and clinical studies. This balance between resis­ tance to infection and tolerance of it might be the key to understanding the molecular mechanisms of sepsis.
Department of Infection Sciences, Southmead Hospital, Westbury-on-Trym, Bristol BS10 5NB, UK

We thank Fergus Hamilton for raising a relevant caveat in sepsis immunology— ie, the potentially protective effect of immunosuppression in particular settings of sepsis. Hamilton high­ lights the case of solid organ transp­lant recipients, an immunesuppressed collective for whom some observational studies report lower mortality from sepsis. These findings imply that solid organ transplantassociated immunosuppression could conceivably buffer or prevent the deleterious (especially the early) effect of hyperinflammation in sepsis. In agreement with this notion, transplantation-related neutropenia has been suggested to have a protective role in septic shock.[1]

Although we sympathise with this concept, we believe that studies in solid organ transplant recipients must be interpreted with caution given the interference of numerous confounders beyond those mentioned by Hamilton. First, patients with solid organ transplant tend to be younger than the average patient with sepsis, implying that immune senescence will differentially impinge on both cohorts.[2] Second, the occurrence of immunosuppression in patients with sepsis who did not receive a solid organ transplant (ie, because of cancer therapy or prolonged treatment with steroids in chronic respiratory diseases). Third, organ failure is the major contributor to death in sepsis. In patients undergoing www.thelancet.com/infection Vol 20 March 2020

However, in the original paper,[3 563] (94%) of 601 Pakistani children were older than 9 months and therefore eligible for vaccination. However, in the original paper,[3 563] (94%) of 601 Pakistani children were older than 9 months and therefore eligible for vaccination. The remaining 38 children were younger than 9 months, of whom five (13%) were infected with measles. In their crude analysis, Murray and www.thelancet.com/infection Vol 20 March 2020

In their crude analysis, Murray and www.thelancet.com/infection Vol 20 March 2020. Rasmussen[3] reported that measles affected 13 (8%) of 166 children who were vaccinated when they were aged 9 months or older, 15 (9%) of all 172 vaccinated children, and 54 (51%) of all 106 unvaccinated children. After controlling for the effects of religious group and age, the vaccine efficacy in the Ismaili children younger than 8 years was found to be even lower, especially in those children vaccinated before age 1 year.[3]

This protective effect remained (albeit weakened) after adjusting for relevant confounders—with an odds ratio of 0·83 (95% CI 0·79–0·87) for inhospital mortality.2. In a smaller study by Kalil and colleagues,[3 123] solid organ transplant recipients with blood culture-proven sepsis were age and sex matched with 246 controls. Despite having more comorbidities and higher scores on the quick sepsisrelated organ failure assessment, solid organ transplant recipients had lower 28-day mortality, with a hazard ratio of 0·22 (95% CI 0·09–0·54).[3]

summary: An important determinant of whether or not 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) will cause a global pandemic is its ability to become established upon its importation to a new country.
Statement on the second meeting of the International Health Regulations (2005) Emergency Committee regarding the outbreak of novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV).
Cases of 2019-nCoV infection have so far been reported in 24 countries, yet little human-to-human transmission outside of China has occurred.

The key quantity governing whether or not 2019-nCoV can establish and generate a sustained outbreak on arrival in a new country is the reproduction number, R, which represents the average number of individuals that each infector will transmit the virus to.
In the ongoing outbreak, assuming an R of 2·2, as reported by Li and colleagues,[1] just over half of infections must be prevented to bring R below 1.

There is little evidence to suggest presymptomatic transmission of 2019-nCoV.[2] Even if 20% of infections are occurring because of presymptomatic infectors, 80% of infections would be due to symptomatic infectors.

Because only slightly more than half of infections need to be prevented to bring R below 1, effective isolation of symptomatic hosts alone should be sufficient to prevent sustained outbreaks of 2019-nCoV outside China.
With fast isolation of symptomatic individuals alone, including self-isolation of those with mild symptoms, sustained outbreaks outside of China can be prevented.

The authors are concerned about the data presented in one of the Articles.[1] For example, in the table the same number (54/106) is listed for the study by Murray and Rasmussen[3] regarding the number of measles infections in unvaccinated infants younger than 9 months and the number of infections in unvaccinated infants aged 9 months and older.
The remaining 38 children were younger than 9 months, of whom five (13%) were infected with measles.

In a large, retrospective hospital dataset, Donnelly and colleagues[2] showed that in-hospital mortality for severe sepsis in patients with solid organ transplant was nearly half that of patients without (5·5% vs 9·4%).

This protective effect remained after adjusting for relevant confounders—with an odds ratio of 0·83 (95% CI 0·79–0·87) for inhospital mortality.[2] In a smaller study by Kalil and colleagues,[3 123] solid organ transplant recipients with blood culture-proven sepsis were age and sex matched with 246 controls.
The authors thank Fergus Hamilton for raising a relevant caveat in sepsis immunology— ie, the potentially protective effect of immunosuppression in particular settings of sepsis.
Hamilton high­ lights the case of solid organ transp­lant recipients, an immunesuppressed collective for whom some observational studies report lower mortality from sepsis.
These findings imply that solid organ transplantassociated immunosuppression could conceivably buffer or prevent the deleterious effect of hyperinflammation in sepsis.

Introduction: An important determinant of whether or not 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) will cause a global pandemic is its ability to become established upon its importation to a new country.
Statement on the second meeting of the International Health Regulations (2005) Emergency Committee regarding the outbreak of novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV).
Results: Cases of 2019-nCoV infection have so far been reported in 24 countries, yet little human-to-human transmission outside of China has occurred.

The key quantity governing whether or not 2019-nCoV can establish and generate a sustained outbreak on arrival in a new country is the reproduction number, R, which represents the average number of individuals that each infector will transmit the virus to.
In the ongoing outbreak, assuming an R of 2·2, as reported by Li and colleagues,[1] just over half of infections must be prevented to bring R below 1.

There is little evidence to suggest presymptomatic transmission of 2019-nCoV.[2] Even if 20% of infections are occurring because of presymptomatic infectors, 80% of infections would be due to symptomatic infectors.

Because only slightly more than half of infections need to be prevented to bring R below 1, effective isolation of symptomatic hosts alone should be sufficient to prevent sustained outbreaks of 2019-nCoV outside China.
With fast isolation of symptomatic individuals alone, including self-isolation of those with mild symptoms, sustained outbreaks outside of China can be prevented.

The authors are concerned about the data presented in one of the Articles.[1] For example, in the table the same number (54/106) is listed for the study by Murray and Rasmussen[3] regarding the number of measles infections in unvaccinated infants younger than 9 months and the number of infections in unvaccinated infants aged 9 months and older.
The remaining 38 children were younger than 9 months, of whom five (13%) were infected with measles.

In a large, retrospective hospital dataset, Donnelly and colleagues[2] showed that in-hospital mortality for severe sepsis in patients with solid organ transplant was nearly half that of patients without (5·5% vs 9·4%).

This protective effect remained after adjusting for relevant confounders—with an odds ratio of 0·83 (95% CI 0·79–0·87) for inhospital mortality.[2] In a smaller study by Kalil and colleagues,[3 123] solid organ transplant recipients with blood culture-proven sepsis were age and sex matched with 246 controls.
Conclusion: The authors thank Fergus Hamilton for raising a relevant caveat in sepsis immunology— ie, the potentially protective effect of immunosuppression in particular settings of sepsis.
Hamilton high­ lights the case of solid organ transp­lant recipients, an immunesuppressed collective for whom some observational studies report lower mortality from sepsis.
These findings imply that solid organ transplantassociated immunosuppression could conceivably buffer or prevent the deleterious effect of hyperinflammation in sepsis.

findings: In a large, retrospective hospital dataset, Donnelly and colleagues[2] showed that in-hospital mortality for severe sepsis in patients with solid organ transplant was nearly half that of patients without (5·5% vs 9·4%)

For example, in a large, retrospective hospital dataset, Donnelly and colleagues[2] showed that in-hospital mortality for severe sepsis in patients with solid organ transplant was nearly half that of patients without (5·5% vs 9·4%). This protective effect remained (albeit weakened) after adjusting for relevant confounders—with an odds ratio of 0·83 (95% CI 0·79–0·87) for inhospital mortality.[2]

Despite having more comorbidities and higher scores on the quick sepsisrelated organ failure assessment, solid organ transplant recipients had lower 28-day mortality, with a hazard ratio of 0·22 (95% CI 0·09–0·54).[3]

In a large Danish cohort study,4 3092 renal transplant recipients were matched with population controls, and despite having approxi­mately ten times the incidence of pneumonia, the mortality rate in each episode was approximately half that of the general population (7% vs 14%)
